Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> ``nheqminer -v -l poolhost:port -u YourPublicVerusCoinAddress.newuser -p x -t 4``
You might want to use less threads than total, maybe ``-t 3`` or ``-t 2`` because it's a laptop, unless you have really good cooling.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dakgnosis> @Godballz I guess what I'm concerned with is more so that anyone can take up an important name and basically keep it forever, even as a dead chain. Unless you can reuse names, I could see this as an issue. Kinda like Bitcoin.com being owned by BCash

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> I imagined that they'd be reusable after they stopped being paid for but I have no idea, maybe that isn't doable and that is a good point  @dakgnosis

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <dakgnosis> The other concern is case sensitivity, because people can get duped into accepting verus coin, rather than Verus coin and end up ripped off (if my understanding is correct about creating blockchain names). These are little things, but preventing some of these phishing vectors is important.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Good points to think about. At first thought, I likely would have sided against case sensitivity till I read what you wrote. It would be cool if some of the code savvy types had the option to create their own unique wallets to help combat that. Seems there are a lot of ins and outs and that's only what we can see now, I can only imagine the mess of wires and hoses under the hood, most users will never see, that Mike and fellow devs had to sort to get us to here. Its reassuring to know that the project continues to grow.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> I cant wait to see some of the PBaaS use cases we can't even picture yet till we see em in action. This should open up a new level of usability in blockchain tech and I truly cant wait to see how itll be used

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Thanks, and hopefully, it's not a mess of hoses and wires even under the hood ðŸ˜ƒ there are core protocols constructed from relatively simple and sound cryptographic principles and primitives, including the Merkle Mountain Range with the ability to prove any block and commit to its power that is maintained for every chain, including Verus in the PBaaS system. This is combined with enhanced crypto conditions that allow Komodo style custom consensus transactions to include more data that is part of the transaction and can carry parameters and have flexible destinations that include normal blockchain addresses or combinations of programmatic and normal addresses. All function is actually built over relatively simple and primitive protocols and rules, which essentially employ the same original principles of Nakamoto consensus, only applied across a many blockchain ecosystem.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Merge mining is achieved with a new, flexible block header format that can carry useful data about each of 15 chains in the same header space otherwise used for an Equihash solution. This also depends on sharing a hash algorithm, which is made easier with a hash algorithm that can be effectively mined on the most available hardware. On that note, @Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining, the community's leading miner developer and developer of a VerusHash 2.0 ARM miner, just posted a pull request that @Asher is looking reviewing/testing now (as will I) and when validated. will enable ARM/RPi compilation and use of Verus nodes. Though I don't know if these are optimized yet for mining, it's exciting to think of inexpensive merge mining and staking chains run by a small Raspberry Pi farm working with faster merge mining cores to mine and notarize many simultaneous chains.
